key_points.interpretations: The study investigates the classification of rose plants using machine learning models.
key_points.implications: Machine learning, especially Random Forests (RF), can enhance the efficiency of plant species identification, reducing manual labor and time.
key_points.limitations: Deep learning models' performance was constrained, potentially due to the small dataset size. RF performance optimization was specifically emphasized.
key_points.more_information: Various classification algorithms were compared, with SVM achieving the highest accuracy on feature set 1, and ensemble models demonstrating superior performance compared to individual classifiers, except SVM.

required_fields.dataset_information: The dataset consists of images of rose leaves, captured with a 23MP camera under controlled lighting, comprising 10 classes with a resolution of 1080 × 1920 pixels. It was split into a 60% training and 40% testing ratio.
required_fields.additional_methods: Performance optimization of Random Forest by tuning parameters such as number of trees and tree depth, along with the use of Selective Features and Deep Learning models (CNN, LSTM, RestNet).
